When I got this for Christmas in 1999 along with Half-Life, I didn't even know what it was.
When I got home two days later and installed it, my family wouldnt have access to our computer again.
I used to trade off every 5 deaths or 20 kills with my little brother until the late hours of the night. When I would get in trouble, TFC would be taken away, and I would have to go outside and play. I can still remember my best friends names, though I doubt they still play it. I can even still remember my favorite medic. I remember mulching until I could finally kick the ♥♥♥♥ out of anyone (this was before stat tracking, though I would assume the hours would be in the thousands.) VIP, Climb, and Jump maps were perfect to kill time and be silly with all your friends.
Though I havent played since TF2 came out, I miss this game more than anything ever. Definitely the fondest memory I have as a child. This game made me fall in love with Sierra (VALVE), and to know what real FPS's should be like.
I have purchased this game three times after the initial gift, to install on friends and girlfriends computers so that I could play at their houses.
Buy this even if it's just to have it in your collection and you never play it. At least you can say that you have it and pretend that you are OG.
I love you TFC.

reviewText:
Team Fortress Classic has nothing to do with Team Fortress 2. They are completely different games with different mechanics, although the classes seem similar.

General:
-TFC has grenades.
-Classes also have armor.
-Health Pool is different.
-Bhop is possible.
-While in TF2, the best gamemodes are Control Points, King of the Hill and Payload, in TFC it is actually Capture the Flag.

Scout:
-In TFC, he is used for his speed to cap the flag, rarely fights.
-No double jump. Concussion grenades are used and they are way more powerful.
-No Scattergun, has only a weak shotgun and a Nailgun used against sentries.

Soldier:
-Soldier has normal grenades and nail grenades - which shoot nails in 360 degrees and deal damage.
-Has a normal weak shotgun and a more powerful one.

Pyro:
-No airblast.
-Flamethrower deals damage depending on the amount of armor the victim has.
-Has an Incendiary Cannon which acts as a Rocket Launcher, but sets enemies on fire.
-Has normal grenades and Napalm grenades - which set enemies on fire.

Demoman:
-No Stickybomb Launcher, replaced by the Pipebomb Launcher. Pipebombs don't stick to surface.
-The Grenade and Pipebomb Launcher share the same ammo pool.
-Has a single-barrel shotgun.
-Has a detpack which has the ability to clear obstacles and open new entrances.
-Has normal grenades and MIRV ones - they split into smaller grenades which explode.

Heavy:
-Has 2 shotguns.
-Also has MIRV grenades.

Engineer:
-Cannot pick-up buildings.
-Has powerful EMP grenades which blow up the enemy's ammo and cause damage.

Medic:
-Medic is also used for capping flags because of his speed and concussion jumping ability, but is more powerful than Scout.
-Can infect classes with his medpack.
-No Medigun therefore no Ubercharge.
-His super nailgun is good against sentry guns.

Sniper:
-Basically TF2 sniper with the Classic and grenades.

Spy:
-Has a Tranquilizer Gun.
-Has a shotgun.
-Can feign death.
-Has Hallucination Grenades.

Civillian is the last class which is used in special gamemodes.

Teams are pit against each other where Red uses defensive classes to protect their flag from Blue, which use mainly Scouts and Medics to capture it.

The community is very small and there are only a couple of servers at a time, but the game is a classic and I recommend it.

reviewText:
If anyone were to ask me what my favourite video game of all time is, my reply to that question would be Team Fortress Classic. Team Fortress Classic is a remake of a Quake mod known as Team Fortress. Team Fortress was made in 1996 by three Australians named Robin Walker, John Cook, and Ian Caughley. Team Fortress became very popular, and it was so popular that these three men got hired by Valve with plans to make a game called Team Fortress 2. Team Fortress 2 went through many changes, and it was eventually released, but before Team Fortress 2 came, there was Team Forterss Classic. Team Fortress Classic was made to promote Half-Life as well as provide something for the Team Fortress community to play while Team Fortress 2 was being worked on. This game, made for those simple reasons, ended up being what I see as a masterpiece.

If you don't understand the concept of Team Fortress, it's actually not very hard to explain at its core. There are two teams, RED and BLUE, and these teams fight over objectives like capturing flags, capturing control points, or silly stuff like fighting over a football (soccer ball). Within a team, there are classes. You can pick from nine classes in Team Fortress. These nine classes are the scout, sniper, soldier, demolitions man, combat medic, heavy weapons guy, pyromaniac, spy, and engineer. Each of these classes have different abilities, weapons, and stats that make their role. For example, the heavy weapons guy has a big gun known as the assault cannon, a lot of health and armor, slow speed, and more resistance to knockback than other classes. This makes him able to play in a defensive role very well.

In Team Fortress Classic, there are many maps you can play on which is one of my favourite parts of the game. There are official maps like 2fort, well, dustbowl, and avanti, but there are also many nice custom maps that this game's community has decided to make themselves. The maps can differ, but a lot of maps play like the official maps. For example, there is a capture the flag map known as bases2k3, and there's nothing to it but capture the flag. However, there's a map known as security_r, and a demoman has to plant a bomb on this map to deactivate the security which can lead to another way to exit and enter the enemy base.

I find the graphics nice even though many people dislike them. If you put this game on software settings, low resolution, and low video quality or use gl_texturemode GL_NEAREST, it gives it a nice classic look. I like the appearance of old-school games so I don't exactly find graphics a huge disadvantage of this game. Also, for its time, these graphics were pretty great. Graphics don't matter as much as gameplay does. You can have a good game with bad graphics and good gameplay, but you can't have a good game with good graphics and bad gameplay.

I also love this game's community. The people in this game are friendly to new players, love to joke around, and they are often very dedicated to this game. This game's community does have bad parts like overly strict admins, elitists, and people who do things like camp spawn. However, these guys aren't really what I would consider the large portion of the community. The community is very strongly against Team Fortress 2, but that doesn't mean they'll hate anyone for liking Team Fortress 2. They just dislike the game. Most new players come from Team Fortress 2, and like I said, the community is willing to help new players.

This game has a very small amount of players, and I hope that it can be revived by getting more players. Very few players stay in this game because they are upset because of its difficulty, but stay around, and you'll learn. It's not impossible, and a lot of new players assume it is. All you really need to know is the basics for the game to become playable, but there are difficult skills dealing with mobility, positioning, and tricks. This game is different from Team Fortress 2, and if you are aware of that, you should treat it like a completely different game. Keep in mind that Team Fortress is the granddaddy of class-based, team-based, multiplayer shooters. You might love it if you play enough.  I'm not a pro at this game, but I enjoy this game every single week.

Final Rating: 10/10

reviewText:
A great underrated classic that still has populated servers 24/7. (You can check for players with the in-game server list, bots won't be shown.) TFC offers one-of-a-kind exciting fast paced gameplay with tons of tactics and ways of playing the game. Easy to get into and enjoy, hard to master. However, you're bound to have fun along the way.

Despite old age, the game has a timeless design with a completely customizable appearance; you can choose from many custom models, sprites, skins, textures etc. There are active community servers hosting many of thousands of custom maps total with official game modes like; Capture The Flag, Control point, Attack/Defend, Escort, Deathmatch as well as custom ones like King of the Hill, Hold or Score Ball etc.

If you're interested in skill jumping (with weapons) there are servers hosting maps made for conc-, grenade-, rocket- and pipe jumping. There are also a lot of movement skill maps where you can climb, bunnyhop, strafe, surf, ramp slide and even water glide (shark) on a few servers. Or if you just want to play some random fun maps and mess around, there's escape, puzzle, hide & seek, sniping, role-play, secret hunting, low gravity and so on. As for mods, there's NeoTF (which gives you extra abilities and buildables), AdminOP (Ent Mod, Radio Mod, Hook Mod) and others.

It's not just one of, but The most popular online multiplayer game of all back in 1999 before CS took the crown. Nowadays, there are barely any FPS games that don't get boring after a few hours. TFC will have you keep coming back for more, time and time again. Without relying on achievements or item drops.

This is an amazing game. You just have to know that if you treat it like Team Fortress 2, you're gonna have a bad time! This game is significantly different than Team Fortress 2. It has a more competitive, fast-paced feeling where people try to work together to complete the objective. If you're used to Team Fortress 2, you have to know some differences before you get in game, get your ♥♥♥ wooped then go to write a negative review about this.

Scouts are not designed for combat and are just for completing the objective. Getting a single kill as a scout is hard to do.  I personally like this scout concept over the Team Fortress 2 one. The people that still want a fast combat class in the game, don't worry! There's still a class for that. Recently, Team Fortress 2 got a new rifle called the 'Classic'. If you know how that works, you can grasp the concept of the classic sniper pretty well. Although, the TFC sniper does not suck as much as the classic. Soldier is the same except he has two shotguns. On the topic of shotguns, there are two of them. A double-barreled one that does more damage yet a slower fire rate and a slower reload and a single-barreled one that does more damage yet a faster fire rate and a faster reload. Shotguns in this game have no fall-off.

Demoman is pretty similar. Your pipebomb launcher is your stickybomb launcher as Team Fortress 2 players are used to. Except the pipeboms do not stick. You have a single-barreled shotgun and you can place an instakill detpack that explodes in 5, 20, 50 seconds. The detpack can also be used to open entrances. Medic is the most changed class. Medic is for combat, healing, and capturing objectives. Your medkit can infect enemies and you have two shotguns. You also have a conc grenade that you can use to conc jump which we'll go over later. HWGuy has the same difference as soldier. You still have a minigun, but you have two shotguns.

Pyro is weaker than his Team Fortress 2 counterpart. Your main job is to confuse and it is not to wreck. You have an incendiary RPG and you cannot airblast. Spy is the second most different when compared to his Team Fortress 2 counterpart. You have a double-barreled shotgun, a pistol that slows enemies down, and a nailgun. You can disguise still and you can do a crappy feign death that makes you turn into a corpse. No one falls for it and it doesn't even show up in the killfeed. It's good for hiding yet it sucks for tricking. YES BACKSTABS STILL EXIST. Engineer is pretty similar. You cannot upgrade dispensers and teleporters, but you can upgrade sentry guns. Sentry guns can be upgraded in 1 hit as long as you have 130 cells (metal). You also have a weak railgun that's more for finishing off rather than taking on a full health target. Dispensers only give armor and ammo, but no health.

General Differences:

There are grenades. Grenades. Every Team Fortress Classic class has a frag grenade (except scout), and a special grenade. Scout has two special grenades.

Movement is a lot more intricate. You can jump with grenades and bunnyhop.

There are more gamemodes and maps.

On flag capturing maps, you don't take the flag back to your flag and you take it to somewhere else.

There is armor.

Team Fortress Classic is a FPS developed and released by Valve Corporation in 1999. It is the sequel to the popular Quake mod, Team Fortress, now remade with the Half-Life engine. And it is the prequel to our favorite Party Simulator, Team Fortress 2. Matches in Team Fortress Classic pit two teams against each other, with each team member having access to nine distinct classes. Competition takes place in a variety of scenarios, usually capture the flag, VIP protection, or territorial control. Since its release, the game has undergone significant upgrades to player models and game modes.
I'll just say it right now guys, this game is GREAT. The classes, the graphics (Aged rather well, considering it was 99), the fast action and variety of weapons etc. I think it's actually near perfect.....Gameplay-wise.

reviewText:
Team Fortress Classic is a complete joy. At first it's a hard game to jump into and can be quite annoying from time to time. There are many things that make this game what it is.

First off, this game set the standard for what every class-based shooter should be. From the fast-running scout to the hefty Heavy Weapons Guy, this game introduces most-needed diversity in what any game should have to keep it running, and to keep players playing. Sometimes, however, it just doesn't seem like the classes are doing what they should. On maps like 2fort (CTF) or Dustbowl (TC), the Medics are the ones that are the guys pushing the flag by using their frag and concussion grenades to propel themselves towards the capture point, rendering the Scout useless and completely diverts the MEDIC'S role away from what it seems.

The game play of this game will keep you sitting at your desk for hours on hours. The on-going struggle to carry a piece of cloth on a pole to an enemy base will be as if you're running with a piece of pie dangling in front of you -- Long and annoying at first, but rewarding in the end. The stalemates of the grenade tosses at the beginning of matches can be aggravating, but you'll feel like a secret agent slipping through as a spy.

Overall, this game is absolutely marvelous, and will live on forever. This game is worth the five bucks, it's tons of fun, and it will keep you entertained for years to come.

Team Fortress Classic is Valve’s second game in their “Classic” series, this one is a remake of the unofficial online shooter built off of Quake and QuakeWorld.

The game was a really good idea and it all comes together pretty well, all of the classes are refined to feel more unique and are redesigned to look more like distinguished characters rather than a bunch of Quake Rangers with different suits.

Team Fortress never had any maps, so they followed what Counter-Strike did and remade 3 popular custom maps that the community previously made as followed: 2 Fortresses, Canalzone, and the Rock. And they’ve all been completely remade to be more modern and they look great.

Same follows with the modes, all the new and official modes are based from the unofficial modes such as Dustbowl and Crossover.

There isn’t much more to say other than the fact that the whole game just feels like a huge tribute to Quake and it’s fans that contributed to Team Fortress and helped shape what it is known as today, then turned it into a very well-polished stand-alone shooter.

The game is $4.99 and it’s a must-have for anybody who played and enjoyed the original, but I don’t recommend it if you don’t even have a clue what Quake is to begin with.

reviewText:
I remember playing this game my freshman year of high school in my best friend's basement while watching the James Bond Christmas marathon on TBS in late 1999.

Half-Life was in the middle of changing gaming forever. We didn't know that at the time, we just loved playing it. The multiplayer was fun, but shallow. It didn't involve any strategy beyond kill the other team more than they kill you. But Half-Life included a copy of Team Fortress Classic, and I absolutely fell in love with this game.

TFC involved a team of classes, each with different abilities, weaknesses and weapons. This was rare back then. It meant that you had variety in how you played the game and team cooperation could mean the difference between winning and losing. The best map was 2fort and camping the flag room as a Heavy was a favorite.

Team Fortress Classic will always have a special place in my heart. It is one of the best first person shooters ever released. The game still has a small community, mostly made up of PC gamers in their 30s like myself. Long may it last. If you've never played the game before, it's an important installment in the FPS genre. Give it a try.

I enjoyed TF2, but TFC is the ultimate brother here. TFC follows the same rules as before, 9 classes, two teams, hundreds of maps, and a lot of killing. TF2 I never liked due to the serious unbalancing of the game, and yes TFC is a tad unbalanced too, but TF2 took it too far. That being said, It's nice to play TFC because I feel as if newcomers have a slighter chance of getting kills, BUT, if you are a newcomer, YOU WILL BE CRUSHED because this game is a tad dead meaning many experienced players do play this. As far as I know, there are about only 5 dedicated servers left for REAL players only, no bots. Drippy's 2fort is one of them that always seem populated, but I hope you don't mind playing 2fort for awhile since that seems to be the only popular real server left.

The graphics are from Half Life 1, sooo you should get an idea of what it looks like. As for sound, nothing really, just explosions, guns being shot off, turrents, doors opening, grunts from jumping, ETC.

The gameplay in this does require a bit more skill so mastering it is really hard. Snipers will pick you off instantly, Soldiers will destroy you, ETC. Haha, the gameplay is quite fun though, but remember, each class isn't for everybody, so you may need to experiment some if you wanna figure out what's best for you. My favorite is the Scout and Engineer. My only complaint in this game...are the grenades. As much as I love TFC, the grenades are absolutely overpowered and spammed to hell. The thing about grenades are that their blast radius is HUGE and people spam them everywhere. In 2fort, I have been killed too much by opening a door and having a grenade thrown at me and having me killed. Grenade spamfest is almost the name of the game, but once you get used to it, this game is downright fun and awesome.

Sure, this game is sadly dying, but there are still some servers left for real players, there is a server that hosts Dustbowl 24/7 for real players too and it's the second most popular server so if you get bored of 2fort from Drippy's, there is always that server. So help us TFC lovers bring this classic back to life by buying it. It's only $5.00, and it will offer you hours of fun on end. Many sleepless night I've had on TFC, trust me. I have almost 50 hours in this game and I know that I will still keep playing more in the future. So buy TFC today! You have nothing to lose other than your social life.

reviewText:
Is this game bad? No. This game is obviously a good little shooter that was once THE king of online gaming before the mod known as Counter-Strike came along and it was replaced by the admittedly better Team Fortress 2. But why did I not recommend it? Because fifteen years ago this game was FULL of players well into the 2000s. Now only a special few still play the game. It's a shame because its actually quite a nice little gem to have in your inventory and show off to your friends.

Pros:
- A good selection of weapons that you wouldn't find in Team Fortress 2 (Pyro has a fire nuke!)
- Pure nostalgia entering servers that are 10 years old and still have Scatman music playing in the background.
- One shot snipers.
- Much harder to play and understand. Very rewarding.

Cons:
- Unfortunately those same weapons I mentioned before do barely any damage. (Pyros Flamethrower does 3dmg!)
- Serious balance issues (Pyro is the worst class in the game)
- GRENADES. THEY SHOULDN'T EXIST IN A GAME LIKE THIS.
- Hardly anyone plays anymore.

Overall you should spend that five bucks if you truly want to see what this game is about. Otherwise I would be recommending Team Fortress 2 or any of the other First Person Shooters.

Also to any Aussie players, there is one local server but it has a password on it. Thus you may need to use the US servers.

reviewText:
Abandon (almost) everything you know about Team Fortress 2, because this remake of the original mod is more to Quake (the game the original Team Fortress mod was based apon) than it's financial titan of a sequel (prequel?).

This game is fast paced and has grenades. What more is there to know? Well, for one thing, it is the ghetto of multiplayer FPS'. Meaning, functions such as objective mechanics and pre-round/round time are map-based, and time is not shown on the HUD, it's generally shown through a server-side command. Other than that, it's quite fun, if not unfogiving, but what fun is there in a game if it offers you little challenge and doesn't punish you for not meeting said challenge?

I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys fast-paced team-centric gameplay, unfortunately it's not exactally bursting with players every day. Most servers are full of bots, and the one that don't have mods that, while not always detering from the gameplay, tend to not retain the original gameplay fully.

Needs Steam Trading Cards. That would attract new players. Or not. Never know.

reviewText:
This is a very fun first-person-shooter. This comes from a person who mainly likes half-realistic games like Counter-Strike.
The graphics are of course dated 1999, includes whacky physics and animations, also voice chat will make your character's mouth move. Sounds are mostly recycled from Half-Life, aswell as the robotic announcer. Gameplay is a ton of fun, not too realistic, you have your 9 classes all with different roles, a handful of different game modes and maps. There aren't many active servers with players, so you'll play against third-party bots most of the time, but you would get your a** kicked if there were some TFC Veterans in here still. This game also screams teamwork, not like teamwork in Call of Duty, but also not like teamwork in Left 4 Dead.

TL;DR, Little multi-player-only, semi-futuristic, first-person-shooter that is not too active, but even 15+ years after date, is still fun to play.

reviewText: Valve rather blatantly ripped off the fan-made mod Fortress Forever with this game, but that's okay, because they did a great job. The move away from the clunky Source engine makes all the crazy movement tricks much smoother to pull off, and the general feel of the game is improved, especially when you take into account the vastly reduced loading times and system requirements. There is also more character in this installment, which has bloodier gibs, more distinctive maps, and a generally fresh feeling, which Fortress Forever can only hint at. Frankly, TFC makes Fortress Forever feel like a cheap knockoff itself.

reviewText:
While Team Fortress Classic was once at the pinacle of greatness, it has since declined greatly for modern or new gamers. Today, very few servers host this game, and many of them are die-hard veterans which do not seem to welcome new players help populate this mostly dead game. Because of this, simply getting into this game can be difficult, both with the terrible class balance (Soldiers, Engineers, and Heavies dominate) and spam of grenades.

However, there are some good points on this game, of course. The fast paced action is a bit more with the bunny hop exploit which is the dumbest thing in this game, than the actual gameplay personally. But regardless, keeps you on your toes. The classes do have different gameplay styles, but specifically the Medic is played outside of intent as a combat class. This was the same case in early versions of Team Fortress 2, but the Medic was only shut down of its combat strength for good in TF2. Many of these good points are truly up to an opinion, and things such as graphics and its engine are more fact than opinion.

Overall, Team Fortress Classic is more for older gamers, and those familier with Quake and such. Every TFC session I have has me feel like I wasted my time and forced myself to even play. Any good point in this game comes down to more of an opinion standoff for many, and it is very rare do I have a glimmer of fun. If you came from Team Fortress 2, like myself, and wanted to try this out, I recommend you do not. And if I had to score Team Fortress Classic, I would give it a 6/10. Thank you for reading this short review.

reviewText:
7.5/10

***Yes, this is a good game however it hurts my heart to make it not recommended. The gameplay, mechanics, physics, and everything about this bundle of joy is amazing, and very enjoyable. Although I have not recommended this game, I still give it a strong 7.5/10. The reason I cannot recommend this is because of the more recent creation of Team Fortress 2, the Team Fortess Classic community is dying out. It's difficult to find a password-free, public server with a decent amount of players on it. If you do see a server with 'players', there's a possibility that the 'players' are bots, therefore abysmal at the game. On the rare occasion, you might find a server that actually has players on it. This is ALSO a problem. The likeliness is high that the players on the server are very good Team Fortress Classic players, and have years of experience. As a latecomer, it is very difficult to become even decent at the game because of the simple fact you get completely anialated by all of the other players. One thing I must note is that, if you are a good, or even the best Team Fortress 2 player in the world, don't get this game with high-expectations. The combat style is very different, and very fast-paced. Even with years of experience in Team Fortress 2 it takes much time and dedication to get good at this game, and be able to have fair fights with other players. Another thing which is enjoyable is that despite the fact some players are very good, all of the loadouts for each class are the same, therefore every player in theory should have an equal chance, however this obviously varies on the fact some players are extremely good, like I previously mentioned.

NOTE: The reason I have low playtime on this game is because I had it and used to play it before steam began to count playtime. Even before steam existed. I would take a rough estimate and say that I have between 150-200 hours of playtime in this game total.

so I eventually picked this thing up hoping for TF2 without the roblox community.

What I got wasn't what I was expecting, but great nonetheless.  TFC is a quake-style shooter, nothing to it.  Low skill floor, high skill ceiling.  You may have a bit of trouble at first but as soon as you get a good understanding of bunnyhopping and the occasional grenade jump, you're ready to go.

Perhaps it doesn't have a lot of players, but you know what?  No big deal.  This game's so much fun, I don't mind only seven servers.  As long as you avoid playing Drippy's 2fort, this game is just great all around, from its leftover quake mechanics to its completely different weapons and style.  Its gamemodes are also a lot of fun-- a Dustbowl where you carry YOUR OWN flag to each point, the insta-capping 5 point Warpath, the civilian escort mission Hunted, and the base assault mission Ravelin.

With many more crazy game mechanics, such as engie's building detonation and the demoman's Detpack that can both be a timebomb and a secret path opener, this game is a must-have for someone looking for a good semi-teambaesd multiplayer deathmatch that focuses on objectives rather than KDR.

Either join an existing server or make your own using Half-Life's dedicated server tool and make a group for this game, it's up to you.

reviewText:
If you are more familiar with TF2 like me... okay, if you started with TF2 like me then you'd have to be curious about Team Fortress Classic and well... it's just not worth it. It just doesn't hold up today, not for people like me.

I probably haven't played it for long enough of course, but do I have to? It's more fast paced sure, but more complicated. Over-complicated, even. It's unbalanced and the GoldSrc engine itself just has weird depth perception... Oh yeah, and nobody plays it anymore. I mean, there are barely any servers with human beings on it for me.

Yes, I know there are still people that like TFC, people that have been raised on TFC the same way I and many others were raised on TF2. And if you're one of them, good for you! That's fine with me. But I just don't like it myself. I'm going to stick with TF2. It's still much better balanced, more simple and it has hundreds of servers that people still play on today.

If you're curious to see what TFC looks like, then I won't stop you from getting it yourself. Just don't say I didn't warn you.
